STATE of Missouri, Respondent,
v.
Willie COLEMAN, Appellant.
No. 36301.
Missouri Court of Appeals, St. Louis District, Division Four.
May 20, 1975.
*28 Charles D. Kitchin, Public Defender, Thomas J. Prebil, James C. Jones, Asst. Public Defenders, St. Louis, for appellant.
John C. Danforth, Atty. Gen., K. Preston Dean, II, Scott A. Raisher, Asst. Attys. Gen., Jefferson City, for respondent.
NORWIN D. HOUSER, Special Judge.
Willie Coleman, convicted of Burglary Second Degree, § 560.070, RSMo 1969, V.A. M.S., and committed to the department of corrections for a period of 10 years, has appealed from the judgment of conviction.
The State's evidence showed that the building housing Alper's Jobbing Company at 1516 Dr. Martin Luther King Drive in the City of St. Louis was burglarized. The latch on the front door was forced open and part of the wood broken away. Six large cartons of shoes were taken from the building. At 12:40 a. m. two police officers observed appellant and another man exiting from an open door at Alper's, each carrying a large cardboard box. These two proceeded across the street and there placed the boxes in the doorway of a building on the north side of the Drive, directly across from the Alper building. After setting down the box he was carrying appellant turned around and "headed out back across the *29 street," walking. There were street lights in the area.
